ratioCategories.description: Measures the company's ability to cover short-term obligations with current assets.

ratios.name: Current Ratio
ratios.interpretation: With a ratio of 2.01, the company has sufficient current assets to cover its short-term liabilities twice over. This aligns with the source document's calculation and indicates a strong short-term solvency position.

ratios.name: Quick Ratio
ratios.interpretation: The Quick Ratio of 0.63 indicates that without selling inventory, the company cannot immediately cover all current liabilities. This highlights a heavy reliance on inventory, which constitutes nearly 68% of current assets.

ratios.name: Cash Ratio
ratios.interpretation: The company holds $155,134 in cash against $978,114 in current liabilities. While low, this is typical for equipment dealers who reinvest cash into fleet and inventory.

ratios.name: Working Capital
ratios.interpretation: Positive working capital of nearly $1M indicates operational stability, primarily driven by high inventory valuations ($1.34M).

ratioCategories.description: Evaluates the company's ability to generate earnings relative to revenue and assets.

ratios.name: Gross Profit Margin
ratios.interpretation: A gross margin of 22.73% is below the target for high-performing rental/sales dealers (often >30-40%). This suggests high Cost of Goods Sold ($3.5M), potentially due to parts costs or rental fleet maintenance.

ratios.name: Operating Profit Margin
ratios.interpretation: Despite lower gross margins, the company maintains a healthy operating margin of 18.56%, indicating effective control over General & Administrative expenses.

ratios.name: Net Profit Margin
ratios.interpretation: The company retains $0.09 for every dollar of sales. This is a solid performance, though it is heavily impacted by the tax provision of $366,423.

ratios.name: Return on Assets (ROA)
ratios.interpretation: Generating a 21.47% return on assets indicates highly efficient use of the asset base to generate profit.

ratios.name: Return on Equity (ROE)
ratios.interpretation: An exceptionally high ROE of 79.52% is driven by the company's leverage (low equity base of $532k relative to assets).

ratios.name: EBITDA Margin
ratios.interpretation: Industry sources suggest a 'Best in Class' EBITDA target of 40%. NLTS-PR is at 17.39%, suggesting room for improvement in operational efficiency.

ratioCategories.description: Assesses the company's long-term debt obligations and leverage.

ratios.name: Debt-to-Equity Ratio
ratios.interpretation: High leverage ratio indicates the company is financed primarily through debt (including floorplan financing) and liabilities ($1.4M) rather than equity.

ratios.name: Debt-to-Assets Ratio
ratios.interpretation: 73% of the company's assets are financed by creditors, which is typical for capital-intensive equipment dealerships but carries higher risk.

ratios.name: Interest Coverage Ratio
ratios.interpretation: With an EBIT of $789,577 covering interest expense of $66,186 nearly 12 times over, the company has no difficulty meeting interest obligations.

ratios.name: Equity Multiplier
ratios.interpretation: Assets are 3.7 times the equity, confirming the high leverage strategy utilized to finance the fleet and inventory.

ratioCategories.description: Measures how effectively the company manages its assets and liabilities.

ratios.name: Asset Turnover
ratios.interpretation: Generating $2.30 in sales for every $1 of assets is efficient, suggesting the company is not holding excessive unproductive assets.

ratios.name: Inventory Turnover
ratios.interpretation: Turnover of 2.61x (approx 140 days) is slow compared to industry averages. This suggests potential overstocking of parts or slow-moving equipment inventory.

ratios.name: Days Sales Outstanding (DSO)
ratios.interpretation: Collecting receivables in ~37 days is better than the standard 45-day benchmark, indicating strong credit control.

ratios.name: Days Payable Outstanding (DPO)
ratios.interpretation: Taking ~49 days to pay suppliers aids working capital but exceeds the DSO, meaning the company collects cash faster than it pays suppliers (positive cash cycle).

ratios.name: Accounts Receivable Turnover
ratios.interpretation: High turnover ratio validates the efficiency of the collections department.

ratioCategories.description: Analyzes the liquidity position based on cash flow generation.

ratios.name: Operating Cash Flow Ratio
ratios.interpretation: The company generates $0.55 in cash for every dollar of current liabilities, which is adequate for ongoing operations.

ratios.name: Free Cash Flow
ratios.interpretation: Positive Free Cash Flow of ~$534k (assuming minimal Capex derived from net fixed asset reporting) indicates the company is generating surplus cash after maintaining its asset base.

ratios.name: Cash Flow to Debt Ratio
ratios.interpretation: The ratio of 0.37 suggests the company could repay roughly 37% of its total debt in one year using operating cash flow, which is a healthy solvency indicator.

overallAnalysis: Based on the audit file 'NLTS-PR FS 12 31 2024 Rev156-1' (used as the closest match to the requested Rev156-3), NLTS-PR demonstrates strong short-term liquidity (Current Ratio 2.01) and solvency (Interest Coverage 11.93), despite maintaining high leverage (Debt-to-Equity 2.70). The company is highly efficient in collecting receivables (DSO 37 days) but shows weakness in Inventory Turnover (140 days), suggesting potential overstocking. While Net Profit Margins (9.32%) are healthy, Gross Margins (22.73%) trail the high-performing benchmarks for the rental/sales industry, likely due to high cost of goods sold. The high ROE (79.52%) is driven largely by the leveraged capital structure.
